SpNote.note: This template MSB does calibrated imaging of a point source target.
SpNote.title: PURPOSE OF THIS MSB

SpNote.note:
Specify your science target in this Target Component - it will be inherited into all Observations within this MSB which do not specifically override it. Thus:
a) If you do not specify a target component in your standard star observation, the sequence will include a slew to the science target position. You can then ask your TSS to find a nearby star of suitable spectral type. The TSS can then slew directly to that star. This allows you to get a good airmass match independent of exactly what time the observations take place. If you do this under flexible scheduling, you should specify in an observer note what your spectral type etc preferences are for the standard star.
b) you do no need to copy this in to the science target observation as it will be inherited into it anyway.
Note that the chop parameters are also set up in this component.
SpNote.title: This Target component

SpNote.note:
This is the Standard Star Observation.
It inherits its Michelle configuration from the components at the start of this MSB, but specifies its own Target information.
SpNote.title: Standard Star

SpNote.note:
This is the Science Target Observation.
It inherits the Target Information and Michelle configuration from the components at the start of this MSB.
SpNote.title: Science Target

SpNote.note:
This series of Observations takes photometry of a standard star and science target in each of the 7.9, 8.8, 9.7, 10.3, 11.6 and 12.5 micron "Silicate" filters. It assumes that all the Observations are sent from the QT to the Queue and executed sequentially.
APHOT data reduction recipes are used. If your science target is sufficiently bright, a point-source photometry result will be produced.
Note that you will need to ensure that the same Standard star Target component is included in each Standard star Observation.
SpNote.title: PURPOSE OF THIS MSB

SpNote.note:
Specify your science target in this Target Component - it will be inherited into all the observations within this MSB which do not specifically override it. Thus:
a) Your flat and arc observation will include a slew to your science target position. This helps to minimise flexure between your flat and arc and your science frames
b) If you do not specify a target component in your standard star observation, the sequence will include a slew to the science target position. You can then ask your TSS to find a nearby star of suitable spectral type. The TSS can then slew directly to that star. This allows you to get a good airmass match independent of exactly what time the observations take place. If you do this under flexible scheduling, you should specify in an observer note what your spectral type etc preferences are for the standard star.
c) you do no need to copy this in to the science target observation as it will be inherited into it anyway.
Note that the chop parameters are also set up in this component.
SpNote.title: This Target component

SpNote.note: This MSB does calibrated imaging over a wide area (6 point mosaic). By default a 15-arcsecond chop is used, north-south.
SpNote.title: PURPOSE OF THIS MSB

SpNote.note:
Specify your science target in this Target Component - it will be inherited into all the observations within this MSB which do not specifically override it. Thus:
a) If you do not specify a target component in your standard star observation, the sequence will include a slew to the science target position. You can then ask your TSS to find a nearby star of suitable spectral type. The TSS can then slew directly to that star. This allows you to get a good airmass match independent of exactly what time the observations take place. If you do this under flexible scheduling, you should specify in an observer note what your spectral type etc preferences are for the standard star.
b) you do no need to copy this in to the science target observation as it will be inherited into it anyway.
Note that the chop parameters are also set up in this component.
SpNote.title: This Target component

SpNote.note:
This is the Science Target Observation.
It inherits the Target Information and Michelle configuration from the components at the start of this MSB.
SpNote.title: Science Target

SpNote.note:
The following sequence will take a chopped mosaic with six positions, covering a region of approximately 140 by 100 arcsecs. You can add extra scan positions if you wish, but always make sure that the final single offset component of 0,0 remains in the sequence, otherwise the DR will fail.
Each scan position will consist of 4 chopped frames.
SpNote.title: Scanning

SpMSB.title: Low & medium resolution point source spectroscopy

SpNote.note: This template MSB takes non-echelle spectroscopy of a point source. First it slews to a standard star, takes flat and arc observations, and then takes science data at the target. Because the target is assumed pointlike, the telescope nods along the slit.
SpNote.title: PURPOSE OF THIS MSB

SpNote.note:
Enter your STANDARD STAR co-ordinates below (this is so that the flat and arc are executed at the location of the standard).
These coordinates will be inherited by the three observations (standard star, target acquisition and target spectroscopy) UNLESS they are over-written by a Target component inside the observation. Obviously, this should be the case for the science target. .
Note - for the standard, you don't need to specify a guide star; the telescope will know to guide on the standard itself.
Note that chop parameters are set up in this target component.
SpNote.title: Standard Star Target component

SpNote.note:
Simply takes a flat field using the Michelle window cover.
Will inherit the standard star position, so that the telescope orientation (and thus instrument flexure) will be the same in the flat..
Be sure to hit the default button in the flat editor if you change the configuration.
SpNote.title: Flat

SpNote.note:
TARGET ACQUISITION - new as of Semester 04A
The "eye" below sets the system into a 10-micron imaging mode and allows the observer to click on the target on the quick-look display. The resulting position is used by the TCS to put the source precisely on the slit.
SpNote.title: Target acquisition

SpNote.note:
This is the Science Target Observation.
It the Michelle configuration from the components at the start of this MSB but specifies the Target coordinates etc. to override the "standard star" target component in the main body of the MSB.
SpNote.title: Science Target

SpNote.note:
Enter your target and guide star details here.
Note that chop parameters are set up in this target component.
SpNote.title: Science Target Target Component

SpNote.note:
TARGET ACQUISITION - new as of Semester 04A
The "eye" below sets the system into a 10-micron imaging mode and allows the observer to click on the target on the quick-look display. The resulting position is used by the TCS to put the source precisely on the slit.
SpNote.title: Target acquisition

SpMSB.title: Low & medium resolution, extended source, chop along slit

SpNote.note: This template MSB takes non-echelle spectroscopy of an extended source. First it slews to a standard star, takes flat observations, and then takes science data at the target. Because the target is extended, the telescope nods off to a sky position (90 arcseconds away by default). Chop is along the slit, by the maximum available guided throw.
SpNote.title: PURPOSE OF THIS MSB

SpNote.note:
Enter your STANDARD STAR co-ordinates below (this is so that the flat and arc are executed at the location of the standard).
These coordinates will be inherited by the three observations (standard star, target acquisition and target spectroscopy) UNLESS they are over-written by a Target component inside the observation. Obviously, this should be the case for the science target. .
Note - for the standard, you don't need to specify a guide star; the telescope will know to guide on the standard itself.
Note that chop parameters are set up in this target component.
SpNote.title: Standard Star Target component

SpNote.note:
Simply takes a flat field using the Michelle window cover.
Will inherit the standard star position, so that the telescope orientation (and thus instrument flexure) will be the same in the flat..
Be sure to hit the default button in the flat editor if you change the configuration.
SpNote.title: Flat

SpNote.note:
TARGET ACQUISITION - new as of Semester 04A
The "eye" below sets the system into a 10-micron imaging mode and allows the observer to click on the target on the quick-look display. The resulting position is used by the TCS to put the source precisely on the slit.
SpNote.title: Target acquisition

SpNote.note:
This is the Science Target Observation.
It the Michelle configuration from the components at the start of this MSB but specifies the Target coordinates etc. to override the "standard star" target component in the main body of the MSB.
SpNote.title: Science Target

SpNote.note:
Enter your target and guide star details here.
Note that chop parameters are set up in this target component.
SpNote.title: Science Target Target Component

SpNote.note:
TARGET ACQUISITION - new as of Semester 04A
The "eye" below sets the system into a 10-micron imaging mode and allows the observer to click on the target on the quick-look display. The resulting position is used by the TCS to put the source precisely on the slit.
SpNote.title: Target acquisition

SpMSB.title: Low & medium resolution, extended source, chop & nod off slit

SpNote.note: This template MSB takes non-echelle spectroscopy of an extended source. First it slews to a standard star, takes flat observations, and then takes science data at the target. Because the target is extended, the telescope nods off to a sky position (90 arcseconds away by default). Chop is also off the slit, by the maximum available guided throw.
SpNote.title: PURPOSE OF THIS MSB

SpNote.note:
Enter your STANDARD STAR co-ordinates below (this is so that the flat and arc are executed at the location of the standard).
These coordinates will be inherited by the three observations (standard star, target acquisition and target spectroscopy) UNLESS they are over-written by a Target component inside the observation. Obviously, this should be the case for the science target. .
Note - for the standard, you don't need to specify a guide star; the telescope will know to guide on the standard itself.

SpNote.title: Flat

The "eye" below sets the system into a 10-micron imaging mode and allows the observer to click on the target on the quick-look display. The resulting position is used by the TCS to put the source precisely on the slit.
SpNote.title: Target acquisition

SpNote.note:
This is the Science Target Observation.
It the Michelle configuration from the components at the start of this MSB but specifies the Target coordinates etc. to override the "standard star" target component in the main body of the MSB.
SpNote.title: Science Target

SpNote.note: Enter your target and guide star details here.
SpNote.title: Science Target Target Component

SpNote.note:
TARGET ACQUISITION - new as of Semester 04A
The "eye" below sets the system into a 10-micron imaging mode and allows the observer to click on the target on the quick-look display. The resulting position is used by the TCS to put the source precisely on the slit.
SpNote.title: Target acquisition

These coordinates will be inherited by the three observations (standard star, target acquisition and target spectroscopy) UNLESS they are over-written by a Target component inside the observation. Obviously, this should be the case for the science target. .

SpNote.title: Target acquisition

SpNote.note: This template MSB takes echelle spectroscopy of an extended source. First it slews to a standard star, takes flat observations, and then takes science data at the target. Chopping is switched off; nodding is off the slit by 90 arcseconds.
SpNote.title: PURPOSE OF THIS MSB

SpNote.note:
Enter your STANDARD STAR co-ordinates below (this is so that the flat and arc are executed at the location of the standard).
These coordinates will be inherited by the three observations (standard star, target acquisition and target spectroscopy) UNLESS they are over-written by a Target component inside the observation. Obviously, this should be the case for the science target. .

SpNote.note:
TARGET ACQUISITION - new as of Semester 04A
The "eye" below sets the system into a 10-micron imaging mode and allows the observer to click on the target on the quick-look display. The resulting position is used by the TCS to put the source precisely on the slit.
SpNote.title: Target acquisition

SpNote.note:
This is the Science Target Observation.
It the Michelle configuration from the components at the start of this MSB but specifies the Target coordinates etc. to override the "standard star" target component in the main body of the MSB.

SpMSB.title: Nod telescope then change pol angle (recommended)

SpNote.note: This template MSB takes imaging polarimetry of a point source (nod size is 7.5 arcseconds, chop size 15). The sequence does a sky-subtaction pair before moving the waveplate, and is the recommended polarimetry mode (Michelle polarimetry is single beam).
SpNote.title: PURPOSE OF THIS MSB

SpNote.note:
Specify your science target in this Target Component - it will be inherited into all Observations within this MSB which do not specifically override it. Thus:
a) If you do not specify a target component in your standard star observation, the sequence will include a slew to the science target position. You can then ask your TSS to find a nearby star of suitable spectral type. The TSS can then slew directly to that star. This allows you to get a good airmass match independent of exactly what time the observations take place. If you do this under flexible scheduling, you should specify in an observer note what your spectral type etc preferences are for the standard star.
b) you do no need to copy this in to the science target observation as it will be inherited into it anyway.
Note that the chop parameters are also set up in this component.
SpNote.title: This Target component

SpMSB.title: Change pol angle and then nod telescope

SpNote.note: This template MSB takes imaging polarimetry of a point source (nod size is 7.5 arcseconds, chop size 15). The sequence does a complete cycle of the weaveplate before nodding to the sky position; it therefore needs extremely stable conditions and is not recommended in normal circumstances.
SpNote.title: PURPOSE OF THIS MSB

SpNote.note:
Specify your science target in this Target Component - it will be inherited into all Observations within this MSB which do not specifically override it. Thus:
a) If you do not specify a target component in your standard star observation, the sequence will include a slew to the science target position. You can then ask your TSS to find a nearby star of suitable spectral type. The TSS can then slew directly to that star. This allows you to get a good airmass match independent of exactly what time the observations take place. If you do this under flexible scheduling, you should specify in an observer note what your spectral type etc preferences are for the standard star.
b) you do no need to copy this in to the science target observation as it will be inherited into it anyway.
Note that the chop parameters are also set up in this component.
SpNote.title: This Target component

SpNote.note: This template MSB takes spectroscopic polarimetry of a point source (nod size is 7.5 arcseconds, chop size 15). The sequence completes a sky-subtaction pair before moving the waveplate.
SpNote.title: PURPOSE OF THIS MSB

SpNote.note:
Simply takes a flat field using the Michelle window cover.
Will inherit the standard star position, so that the telescope orientation (and thus instrument flexure) will be the same in the flat..
Be sure to hit the default button in the flat editor if you change the configuration.
SpNote.title: Flat

SpNote.note:
TARGET ACQUISITION - new as of Semester 04A
The "eye" below sets the system into a 10-micron imaging mode and allows the observer to click on the target on the quick-look display. The resulting position is used by the TCS to put the source precisely on the slit.
SpNote.title: Target acquisition
